Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Climate change and phenological mismatch - an experimental test with cavity nesting bees, cleptoparasites, and floral resources
Award.AbstractNarration:
Species that rely closely upon one another, such as bees and the plants they pollinate, may respond differently to global climate change, with potentially dire consequences such as poor crop pollination and low yields. For instance, pollinators may respond strongly to climate warming and emerge earlier in the growing season, while their preferred flowers respond less strongly and emerge later. This mismatch in timing could severely impact either organism if one relies strongly on the other. The work proposed here would test the importance of such mismatches for cavity-nesting bees and the trees they pollinate, by experimentally manipulating bee springtime emergence. In addition, the proposed work will develop two novel technologies that are critical for this and similar experiments. The first technology will enable bee nests to be warmed in the field and cause the resident bees to emerge earlier in the spring. The second technology will employ tiny labels, similar to bar-codes, that can be placed on the backs of bees. The bees and tags can then be monitored using computer assisted image recognition. By placing a video camera at each nest, this technology will allow researchers to study in detail how bees respond to a warming climate and shifting schedules of flowering.

Understanding and predicting how species and ecological communities respond to global climate change is critical because the pace of climate change over the next few decades may greatly exceed what species have previously experienced over the previous millennium. Since many wild plants and animals provide important services that are critical for human well-being, an understanding of how they may be impacted by climate change is essential for any effort to predict and mitigate these effects. Indeed, bees are the most important pollinators globally, providing pollination services to both agricultural and natural ecosystems. Additionally, the proposed micro-tagging and tracking technologies may redefine how scientists study small mobile organisms, which often have outsized impacts on ecosystems but are difficult to study due to their small size. Finally, one Ph.D. student will be trained, and at least two undergraduate students will gain valuable field and laboratory research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project aimed to conduct preliminary experiments to understand whether changes in the timing (phenology) of springtime activity of cavity nesting mason bees (Osmia species), their floral resources, and their natural enemies will benefit or harm these bee species. To do this we aimed to first, monitor the activities of these bees, their floral resources, and the bee’s natural enemies such as nest parasites; second experimentally manipulate the springtime emergence of the bees by artificially warming their nests; and third, to develop a system to tag and track the bees using small barcode-like tags and video monitoring. 

Despite repeated attempts, we were not able to successfully tag and track the bees. We tagged the bees while they were dormant for the winter, and the bees failed to emerge from their dormancy. This is likely because the bees used up their stored energy when we disturbed them to affix the tags, or because the various glues we tried were toxic to the bees.

Our efforts to artificially warm the Osmia taurus and O. cornifrons bees to advance their springtime emergence was very successful. By increasing the ambient temperature by 5.2°C, we were able to cause the bees to emerge up to one week earlier compared to unwarmed controls. This result is important for two reasons. First, it provides an experimental approach for manipulating these bees to see how they will respond to mismatches in emergence compared to their floral resources and their natural enemies. Second, this may provide an important tool for orchard agriculture that relies on orchard bees to pollinate fruit trees.

We also produced a number of important findings regarding mason orchard bees (Osmia species) at our field site at Morristown National Historical Park, Morristown, New Jersey. First, we found that the vast majority of mason orchard bees that nested in our experimental bee boxes were  Osmia taurus, a non-native bee from east Asia. We found a few Osmia cornifrons, another non-native bee from east Asia, and absolutely no Blue Orchard Bees (Osmia lignaria) that are native to the area. This suggest that the non-native O. taurus is displacing the important orchard pollinator O. lignaria. Second, we found that our mason bees preferred nesting in nest holes that were more spread out in our nest boxes, possibly because this isolation makes them less susceptible to natural enemies such as nest parasites and predators. Third, we found that, globally, plant and pollinator diversity are well correlated, suggesting that their diversity is driven by each other or by common factors.

Throughout the lifetime of this project, we trained two PhD students and more than 20 undergraduate students. Many of the undergraduates conducted their own independent research in addition to contributing to the broader objectives of the project. One of the graduate students is expected to finish their dissertation in fall 2019. The other graduate student earned her PhD in 2018 and is now a University Lecturer an New Jersey Institute of Technology.
